head.title: Wall Street Plays a Guessing Game

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Banking, Finance and Insurance

hedline.hl1: Wall Street Plays a Guessing Game

abstract.p: Data Bank page gives financial market figures for the week; chart; graphs (L)

block.p: A series of economic reports last week calmed some investor's inflation jitters but left others wondering whether the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates again.

Right now, people are trying to read the economic tea leaves and arrive at an indicator of what the Fed will do before it does it, and make investment decisions accordingly, said Barry Berman, head trader for Robert W. Baird & Company.
A series of economic reports last week calmed some investor's inflation jitters but left others wondering whether the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates again.

Right now, people are trying to read the economic tea leaves and arrive at an indicator of what the Fed will do before it does it, and make investment decisions accordingly, said Barry Berman, head trader for Robert W. Baird & Company.

Last week's data provided mixed signals on where the economy was headed. For instance, the government reported that manufacturing growth was unchanged in July and that construction spending fell in June, yet it also said unemployment remained at a three-decade low last month.
The inflation-wary Fed has already pushed rates higher six times in the past 13 months. The Fed's policy-making committee meets next on Aug. 22.
Among the winners last week were financial stocks, like Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers, which stand to benefit from stable rates.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week at 10,767.75, up 256.58, while the Nasdaq composite index closed at 3,787.36, up 124.36.
